questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding long polling?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding long polling?

options.option_text: Long polling opens multiple connections between the client and the server,and the server continuously sends updates to the client in real-time.
Long polling allows the client to make a single request to the server, where theserver holds the connection open until new data is available and then sends the response.
Long polling involves the client repeatedly sending requests at fixed intervalsto the server to check for updates, regardless of whether new data is available.
Long polling uses WebSockets to maintain a persistent, bidirectionalconnection between the client and the server.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.option_text: Cache-Control: no-store prevents caching
Data stored in sessionStorage remains available even after the browser isclosed and reopened.
ETag helps validate cache freshness
localStorage has larger storage limit than cookies

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is false when using the “async” and “await” keywords in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is false when using the “async” and “await” keywords in JavaScript?

options.option_text: The “await” keyword can only be used inside an async function.
The async functions run synchronously, but their await statements executeasynchronously.
The “await” keyword pauses the execution of the surrounding async functionuntil the promise resolves.
The async functions always return a promise, even if the return value is not apromise.

questions.question_text_1: You have a Celery task send_email that needs to run every 10 minutes. How can you schedule it?
question_texts: You have a Celery task send_email that needs to run every 10 minutes. How can you schedule it?

options.option_text: Using @app.task_periodic to run the task every 10 minutes.
Using @app.on_periodic to schedule a periodic task.
Using Celery Beat to schedule periodic tasks.
Celery doesn't support scheduling tasks at fixed intervals; you need to use anexternal scheduler.
The increment mutation will be called immediately after the dispatch.
The incrementAsync action will be executed synchronously, and increment willbe committed before the promise resolves.
The state will be updated after the asynchronous operation completes.
The action will be skipped since mutations cannot be called inside actions.
The watcher will be triggered and log "User object changed: { name: 'Bob',age: 30 }".
The watcher will not be triggered because “name” is a nested property of“user” object.
The watcher will be triggered, but it will only log the new “name” value, i.e.,“Dev”, and not the entire user object.
The watcher will throw an error because deep watching is not supported onnested objects.
Required
Invalid format, Email exists, Required
Required, Email exists
Validating..., Required
The task will immediately execute and print the result 'Task completed'.
The task will execute asynchronously, and 'Task completed' will be printedafter a 10-second delay.
The task will execute synchronously, blocking the main thread for 10 seconds.
None of these

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements are true about Lighthouse?
question_texts: Which of the following statements are true about Lighthouse?

options.option_text: Lighthouse measures various performance metrics, including Time toInteractive and Speed Index.
Lighthouse generates a single score for UI design only.
It can emulate network throttling and device types during performanceevaluation.
Lighthouse focuses exclusively on performance and ignores accessibility.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding the behavior of local storage in Vue.js applications?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding the behavior of local storage in Vue.js applications?

options.option_text: The local storage data persists even after the browser is closed and reopened.
The local storage data is automatically cleared every session.
The local storage can only store strings, and storing objects requires manualserialization and de-serialization.
Vue's reactivity system automatically updates the local storage when bound toa Vue data property.
The class, namely “classB” will always be applied to the div element.
The classes, namely “classA” and “classB” will always be applied to the divelement.
The class, namely “classA” will only be applied to the div element, if thevariable “isClassA” evaluates to true.
The class, namely “classB” will only be applied to the div element, if no variablewith name “isClassA” exists.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements correctly describe the use of asynchronous messaging systems and frameworks?
question_texts: Which of the following statements correctly describe the use of asynchronous messaging systems and frameworks?

options.option_text: Celery allows web servers to offload long-running tasks to worker processes,decoupling task execution from user requests.
Push queues are used for real-time operations, while pull queues are bettersuited for batch processing.
Server-Sent Events (SSE) provide a persistent connection between server andclient, enabling bi-directional communication.
Redis is a high-performance in-memory database that supports Pub/Sub.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about Webhooks?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true about Webhooks?

options.option_text: A Webhook is a method for a server to send real-time data to another serveras an HTTP POST request.
Webhooks are typically used for sending periodic updates at regular intervals.
A client must continuously poll a Webhook URL to receive data.
Webhooks are usually used in event-driven architectures, where an eventtriggers an HTTP POST request to a specified endpoint.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Server-Sent Events (SSE) and WebSockets?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Server-Sent Events (SSE) and WebSockets?

options.option_text: SSE is a two-way communication protocol, while WebSockets areunidirectional.
WebSockets are more suited for scenarios requiring bi-directionalcommunication.
SSE is based on HTTP and can only be used for server-to-client communication,while WebSockets are based on TCP and support both directions.
SSE is an extension of WebSockets, providing enhanced support for server-to-client communication.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are typical use case(s) for Celery tasks?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are typical use case(s) for Celery tasks?

options.option_text: Processing time-consuming or resource-intensive background jobsasynchronously.
Directly handling incoming HTTP requests in web servers.
Scheduling periodic tasks like sending emails or cleaning up the database.
Serving real-time notifications over WebSockets.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and key takeaways** from the exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
#### **1. Web Security & Cookies**
- **Cookie Attributes**:
  - `secure=True`: Ensures cookies are sent only over HTTPS.
  - `samesite='Strict'|'Lax'|'None'`:
    - `Strict`: Blocks cross-site requests.
    - `Lax`: Allows top-level navigations (e.g., links).
    - `None`: Allows cross-site requests (requires `secure=True`).
- **Content Security Policy (CSP)**:
  - `default-src 'self'`: Restricts resources to the same origin.
  - Violations block external scripts (e.g., `<script src="otherurl.com">`).

#### **2. Asynchronous JavaScript**
- **Promises & Async/Await**:
  - `.then()` chains handle resolved promises.
  - `async/await` pauses execution until a promise resolves (but runs asynchronously).
  - Errors propagate to `.catch()` or `try/catch`.
- **Event Loop**:
  - Microtasks (Promises) execute before macrotasks (e.g., `setTimeout`).
  - Example output order:
    ```javascript
    console.log("Start");
    setTimeout(() => console.log("Timeout"), 0);
    Promise.resolve().then(() => console.log("Promise"));
    console.log("End");
    ```
    **Output**: `Start → End → Promise → Timeout`.

- **Long Polling vs. WebSockets vs. SSE**:
  | Technique          | Description                                                                 | Direction       |
  |--------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------|
  | **Long Polling**   | Client holds a request open until the server responds with new data.       | Client → Server |
  | **WebSockets**     | Persistent bidirectional connection.                                        | Duplex          |
  | **Server-Sent Events (SSE)** | Server pushes updates over HTTP (unidirectional).                     | Server → Client |

#### **3. Vue.js**
- **Lifecycle Hooks**:
  - `beforeCreate` → `created` → `beforeMount` → `mounted` → ... → `beforeDestroy`.
  - Example: `ETA` decreases in each hook (Q25).
- **Reactivity**:
  - `data()` properties are reactive.
  - `computed` properties cache results until dependencies change.
  - `watch` can deep-watch nested objects (`deep: true`).
- **Slots**:
  - Named slots (`<slot name="header">`) pass data via `v-slot:header="{ info }"`.
  - Correct syntax: `<template v-slot:header="{ info }">{{ info.title }}</template>`.
- **Vue Router**:
  - Dynamic segments (e.g., `/profile/:userId`) are accessed via `this.$route.params.userId`.
  - Wildcard (`*`) matches unmatched routes (e.g., 404 pages).
- **Vuex**:
  - **Actions**: Handle async operations (e.g., `incrementAsync`).
  - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates (e.g., `increment`).
  - **State**: Single source of truth.

#### **4. Caching & Storage**
- **Cache-Control Headers**:
  - `no-store`: Prevents caching entirely.
  - `ETag`: Validates cache freshness.
- **Storage APIs**:
  | API               | Persistence       | Scope          | Storage Limit | Data Type       |
  |-------------------|-------------------|----------------|---------------|-----------------|
  | `localStorage`     | Persists          | Per-origin     | ~5MB          | Strings (only)  |
  | `sessionStorage`   | Cleared on tab close | Per-tab      | ~5MB          | Strings (only)  |
  | **Cookies**        | Configurable      | Per-domain     | ~4KB          | Strings         |

- **Flask-Caching**:
  - `@cache.cached(timeout=5)` caches responses for 5 seconds (Q23).

#### **5. Task Queues & Background Jobs**
- **Celery**:
  - Offloads long-running tasks (e.g., `send_email`) to workers.
  - **Celery Beat**: Schedules periodic tasks (e.g., every 10 minutes).
  - Example:
    ```python
    @app.task
    def long_task():
        time.sleep(10)
        return "Task completed"
    ```
    - `long_task.delay()` runs asynchronously.

- **Asynchronous Workflows**:
  - **Queue → Process → Callback** (e.g., Q13: `III. Queue → I. Save → II. Callback`).

#### **6. Webhooks & Real-Time Systems**
- **Webhooks**:
  - Server-to-server HTTP callbacks (e.g., GitHub push events).
  - **Event-driven**: Triggered by events (not polling).
- **SSE vs. WebSockets**:
  - **SSE**: Unidirectional (server → client), HTTP-based.
  - **WebSockets**: Bidirectional, TCP-based.

#### **7. Performance Optimization**
- **Lighthouse**:
  - Audits performance (e.g., Time to Interactive), accessibility, and SEO.
  - Emulates slow networks (3G) and devices.
- **Caching Strategies**:
  - Reduce latency by serving cached responses (e.g., Flask-Caching).

---

### **Key Equations/Code Snippets**
#### **JavaScript**
1. **Promise Chaining**:
   ```javascript
   Promise.resolve(1)
     .then(x => x + 1)          // 2
     .then(x => Promise.resolve(x + 1)) // Promise(3)
     .then(x => { throw 'error' }) // Throws 'error'
     .catch(e => e + 4)        // 'error4'
     .then(x => console.log(x)); // Logs 'error4'
   ```
   **Output**: `error4` (Option D).

2. **Async/Await Execution**:
   ```javascript
   async function test() {
     console.log("Start");
     const val = await Promise.resolve(5); // Pauses here
     console.log(val); // 5
     return "End";
   }
   console.log("Begin");
   test().then(data => console.log(data)); // "End"
   console.log("Finish");
   ```
   **Output Order**: `Begin → Start → Finish → 5 → End` (Option B).

3. **`this` Binding**:
   ```javascript
   const obj = { name: "Abhi", greet: function() { console.log(this.name); } };
   const greet = obj.greet;
   greet(); // undefined (loses `this` context)
   ```

#### **Vue.js**
1. **Scoped Slots**:
   ```vue
   <template v-slot:header="{ info }">{{ info.title }}</template>
   ```
2. **Vuex Action**:
   ```javascript
   actions: {
     async incrementAsync({ commit }) {
       await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 1000));
       commit('increment'); // Updates state after 1s
     }
   }
   ```

#### **Python (Flask/Celery)**
1. **Flask Caching**:
   ```python
   @app.route('/time')
   @cache.cached(timeout=5)
   def get_time():
       return str(time.time())  # Cached for 5 seconds
   ```
2. **Celery Task**:
   ```python
   @app.task
   def long_task():
       time.sleep(10)
       return "Task completed"  # Runs asynchronously
   ```

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Web Technologies Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    WebSecurity --> Cookies
    WebSecurity --> CSP
    Cookies --> SecureAttribute
    Cookies --> SameSite
    CSP --> default-src

    AsyncJS --> Promises
    AsyncJS --> AsyncAwait
    AsyncJS --> EventLoop
    Promises --> then-catch
    AsyncAwait --> try-catch

    RealTime --> LongPolling
    RealTime --> WebSockets
    RealTime --> SSE
    LongPolling --> SingleRequest
    WebSockets --> Bidirectional
    SSE --> Unidirectional
```

#### **Graph 2: Vue.js Ecosystem**
```mermaid
graph TD
    VueCore --> LifecycleHooks
    VueCore --> Reactivity
    VueCore --> Components

    VueRouter --> DynamicRoutes
    VueRouter --> WildcardRoutes

    Vuex --> State
    Vuex --> Actions
    Vuex --> Mutations

    Components --> Slots
    Components --> Props
    Slots --> NamedSlots
    Slots --> ScopedSlots
```

#### **Graph 3: Backend & Caching**
```mermaid
graph TD
    Backend --> Flask
    Backend --> Celery
    Flask --> Caching
    Caching --> CacheControl
    Caching --> Redis
    Celery --> TaskQueues
    Celery --> Beat
    TaskQueues --> AsyncTasks
    TaskQueues --> Workers
```

#### **Graph 4: Storage APIs**
```mermaid
graph TD
    Storage --> localStorage
    Storage --> sessionStorage
    Storage --> Cookies
    localStorage --> Persistent
    sessionStorage --> TabScoped
    Cookies --> SmallLimit
    Cookies --> HTTPOnly
```

---

### **Exam Preparation Checklist**
| Topic               | Key Concepts                                                                 | Example Questions          |
|---------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------|
| **Cookies**         | `secure`, `samesite`, `HttpOnly`                                            | Q2                          |
| **Async JS**        | Promise chaining, `async/await`, event loop                                | Q5, Q6, Q9, Q15             |
| **Vue.js**          | Lifecycle hooks, slots, Vuex, reactivity                                   | Q4, Q8, Q11, Q20, Q21, Q26 |
| **Caching**         | `Cache-Control`, Flask-Caching, Redis                                       | Q14, Q23                    |
| **Real-Time**       | Long polling vs. WebSockets vs. SSE                                         | Q3, Q32                     |
| **Celery**          | Task queues, Beat, workers                                                  | Q17, Q24, Q30               |
| **Web Security**    | CSP, XSS prevention                                                          | Q7                          |
| **Storage**         | `localStorage` vs. `sessionStorage` vs. cookies                             | Q12, Q18, Q28               |
| **Webhooks**        | Event-driven callbacks                                                       | Q31                         |
| **Performance**     | Lighthouse, throttling                                                      | Q27                         |
